>>2372901
That's Inambakan in Southern Cebu. Very nice falls consiting of 3 levels. However, not too far away is also Dao Falls(pic related) which is much more majestic, and requires a 30min trek along the stunning river that leads up to it. Almost straight out of a fairytale.
To get to either of these, you can avail of either a tour agency in Moalboal, or if you are not a complete retard on a scooter, you can rent one and go by yourself.

>Would like to a do a few things off the beaten path if possible, any recommendations?
In Bohol, go to Dimiao. There are 4 popular waterfalls there, and it's quite far so barely any tourists there either. You may come accross Kuya RJay, the tour guide there. He's pretty cool and fun. Tell him you hate Russians and he will love you.
If you have time, check out Anda Beach, pretty nice. Also it's close to Cam-Umantad falls and some kino rice terraces.
DON'T RIDE IN THE DARK YOU ARE PLAYING WITH THE DEVIL IF SO. And I'm not talking about getting robbed, I am talking about the traffic hazards, like poorly lit roads that could have obstacles in them that you can't see, borderline psychopathic bus and van-drivers, dogs suddenly running accross the road infront of you.

cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2372901
>>2373189

>Loboc river seems interesting but I've heard mixed reviews about river cruise
It's cool to do once, but that's about it. There are some paved roads that go along the river or close to it so you can check out through that.

>Also chocolate hills and tarsiers... is it crowded and touristy?
Barely any tourists in the Tarsier Sanctuary last time I was there. Be sure to go early.
Chocolate Hills can get quite crowded. However, there's a "secret" area though that you can go to. You can climb ontop of one of the hills there right by the road and have a great view. Pic related
Not too far from the Chocolate Hills there's something called Pangas Falls.

>Also places for food/entertainment, I will try anything.
In Cebu City, check out 8flix & Chill. There they serve Tuslob Buwa. To spoil it for you, it's basically pork brain mixed with chili, onion and onions sauce. It turns into a gravy which you dip "puso", or rice balls in. As disgusting as it might sound to most, it's actually really good. Imagine dipping bread in a buttery gravy full of umami. That's pretty much what it is. It's dirt cheap too, $4 for 10 piece of rice balls and unlimited gravy.
Top of Cebu is another nice restaurant to check out.

In Bohol, Mist is a cool interesting restaurant made in the vernacular style. Molly Bistro is similar, though they primarily serve a Filipino/Viet BBQ fusion.
Bamboo place is usually where the nightlife is in Alona/Tawala.
Be on the lookout for Beefarm Ice cream along Alona Beach. Really delicious. And on that topic, The Buzzz Cafe is pretty nice. Check out Halang Halang, a Bisaya soup similar to Tom Kha Gai.

If you go to Balicasag, don't fucking eat anything there. I am an advocate for promoting Filipino food and even I found the food there very mediocre. Also it's a ripoff, $10 for a single plate of an awful meal. If they still sell barbecue in Virgin Island, I suggest you to avoid the touts. It's good but extremely overpriced.

Cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2372901
>>2373189
>>2373197

>Worth it to rent motorbikes everywhere or is it dangerous?
If you have common sense, you'll be fine most likely. Don't drive like a maniac, get used to the bike first. Don't do steep turns(if you know how to truly countersteer) if there is dust or dirt on the road. Keep an eye on the rear mirrors. If you see a van, bus or any big car approaching you fast, steer to the right shoulder to let them pass. These drivers have no brains, but you don't want them to harm you either.
Before you rent a bike, check that both the front and rear brakes are good, that means you shouldn't have to squeeze/press them too hard to actually stop. Check for air in the tyres, they should be rock hard.
Ask the renters to check oil.
Honk whenever you are passing someone, or think someone who is at perpendicular interchange haven't seen. Use the horn alot to let people know you are there.
Bohol and Siquijor are great places to rent. Coron you won't really need.

>Any way to avoid food poisoning or should I just bring Cipro and pray?
I honestly think it all depends on your gut most of the time. I've been food poisoned here a few times but that was after staying here for many months. Meanwhile, my friend and his gf was here for only 4 days and they both got food poisoned, but not me. But yeah, you are likely to experience some kind of diarrhea sooner or later

cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2372901
>>2373189
>>2373197
>>2373200
>Any other tips/advice for Philippines I'd appreciate.
Use Grab when going around in the cities. Taxi drivers in this region is notorious for ripping people off, although I ironically had no problem using Taxis in Cebu City, the 3 drivers were honest and used a non-rigged meter.
A 10min ride with tricycle should not cost more than P150-200. If they say anything above, haggle or just go for another driver.
Don't be swayed by touts, be on the look for the best deal. If you can't find, give in to them and hear what they offer.
Ignore hawkers unless they have something you really need and can't acquire easily in that moment, eg. drybag.
I suggest you learn how to use the "tabo" when taking a shit. It will save you space not having to bring rolls everywhere.
Don't be afraid to ask locals for directions.
There are probably more stuff but I can't recall much right now.

>Would like to a do a few things off the beaten path if possible, any recommendations?
About Coron, if you have time and money, do a Dugon tour. It's one of my favourite activites I've ever done. Contact this guy for more info:
https://www.instagram.com/freedivewithlouie/

There are also alot of Japanese shipwrecks there from WWII that are worth to check out if you have your scuba cert in place. I think they will only let you dive in the cargo ship as it's very easy to traverse.

It’s more of an /out/ country in my opinion. Lot’s of neat outdoor activities you can do such as hiking, canyoning, scuba diving(BIG emphasis on this one), free diving, surfing, expedition tours, island hopping. Night life can be fun here aswell.
Culture-wise, many will tell you they are Mexicans of Asia, but I rather think they have a maritime Asian culture. Lot’s of emphasis on sea-faring in a tropical climate, with a few Asian elements here and there, and also a few Spanish elements.
In my opinion, the most glaring American influence is in the language, brutalist architecture, basketball, (barely functional) political structure, urban planning and some food items the mutts unfortunately introduced. Reggae is also quite popular in the sea-side communities due to this.
If you’re American(Fil-Ams are notoriously bad at cooking) give the country’s cuisine atleast one more chance by dining in well-regarded establishments such as Manam and Gerry’s Grill. It has potential unironically, but the average flip puts no soul into it.

Besides historically speaking, there are heaps of old shipwrecks around, some of them from WWII. Old Spanish buildings and forts are found around the whole island, and while there are some pre-colonial buildings and slight remains of ruins in the country, they are in areas I would not suggest you to visit on your first trip.
And lastly, the country has some of the finest beaches in the world in my opinion.

Lol saw the thread and thought immediately of Romblon and lo there was the first post. I'll add this though: somewhere near Romblon you don't need to go is Sibuyan island. At the time I had a gf with friends of her family owning a villa at the island that they let us borrow (they wanted her parents to build something there as well). The island itself is very boring. A wildlife sanctuary - there are apparantly tons of unique or endangered birds there. There's basically no soil though, so most foodstuffs are imported by the same 24h ferry and there's not much available (and it's overpriced). The locals grow some rice and a few tomatoes from what I can recall.

Barely any sand beaches (if any) either. There's a waterfall though. Small island as well with a few villages all along the coastline. One resort (closed) and no restaurants or the like. In the evenings you can play basketball or do karaoke with the locals.

What is cool though, is the marble. It's so plentiful alot of stuff is built by it. Like the house we stayed in had a solid marble staircase and pillars because they were made on site. Do go to Romblon though.

>>2374430
> Is it even possible to travel Iceland on a bidget as a student?
Doubt it. You might want to try taking foodstuffs with long shelf life from your home country and cooking your own meals.
If you want to see more than, like, 3 cities and their vincinities then you can forget about hostels, because those don't exist outisde places with large housing base i.e most of fucking Iceland. You'll find single hotels and guesthouses here and there but those obv won't be cheap. Options you have are: rent an rv (not cheap either, but some rental places might have options to just get a 4x4 car with roof tent), camp around (if you have the gear and can plan ahead where to do so) or couchsurfing (which carries with it the risk of your host changing their mind last minute)

> what else is there to see
waterfalls, I guess? Iceland is very boring outside the nature views and the obvious tourist places that every travel guide mentions.

> public transport to go around
You can get to most places, eventually. But there are those that have only 1 or 2 connections a day or suspend service altogether during winter.
You could try hitchhiking, even if it's not the greatest country to do so, someone will eventually stop.

Other than that, good and vibrant northern lights are a rare sight, for hot springs check reykjadalur, it's free (there's a parking fee if you come by car) and at the top of the bathing area over 40C even in winter. No volcanic activity on the surface right now, I'm afraid.
If I could redo my trip, I'd probably go in the summer and just hike across the continent, but you do you.

>>2374430
>public transport to go around Iceland
Trust me when I say this OP, I've researched this extensively when planning my trip to Iceland and while not impossible it is extremely inconvenient and expensive to travel the country by bus. So expensive in that you are probably better off financially renting a vehicle. The bus routes on nice around the capital and southern parts of Iceland are alright but the Eastern Fjords are a pain in the ass to plan around. Some buses don't run on random days like tues and Weds and some in the northern parts of the country don't run on weekends so you're either going to be stuck in a small town in bumfuck nowhere and forced to stay in a overpriced hostel (cheapest ones in Iceland are like $100 USD a night iirc) or going to just catch one expensive bus ride after the next. It's like $75 USD one way on some routes and it will be a few hours longer than just driving. Hitch hiking is a better option at this point imho
https://straeto.is/en
Here's the official bus website if you want to look into it more.

>>2374430
I have been to Iceland multiple times, mainly for hiking and birdwatching.

>budget
Food? Possible, if you buy supermarket food all the time and heat it yourself with a portable stove. It's expensive but it's on par with Scandinavia in general (especially Norway).
Most expensive thing in Iceland was public transport (I rented a car but I took a bus once, 60 fucking euros to take me from my hiking destination back to the parking where I have left my car) and hotels/lodging.
A generic hotel is more expensive than a boutique hotel in central Oslo or Stockholm.
Last time I was there was during the whole world under lockdown in 2020, and some extremely basic hotel in a small southeastern town has cost me around 200 euros per night. Mind you, that was when there weren't any tourist around.
In 2019, it was around 300 for an extremely basic room in a small town. Never tried hostels but I have seen some in Akureyri, Reykjavik, and some other towns. Not sure about the price but it was at least 100 euros per night.

>what else is there to see
Great country for outdoors; however due to the high amount of instawhores ruining the surrounding nature, they made wild camping illegal.
However the hikes are beautiful and there are many species of birds. Combining the two of these make it very worthwhile.
Again, if you're not into outdoor stuff, not into hikes or wildlife, then don't come. The country is already a victim of mass tourism with the masses having no idea what to do apart from taking the same fucking picture.

>and more importantly are there hostels
Yes, in main cities. Some popular small towns as well. However, there are not many of these and the Eastern part of the country is mostly devoid of these, except, again, in main villages and towns such as Egilsstadir.

>public transport to go around
Possibly the worst country in Europe for that matter. Rent a car/bike or get on a tour bus like a boomer.

posts.com:
>>2374612
Northern lights are never guaranteed, so you have to accept that you may not see these. Not only they kinda randomly happen, but you also need crazy good weather. For that alone, Iceland is not the best contender for northern lights because the weather is absolutely batshit, in the sense that you can experience the four seasons in the same day, and the weather is almost always unpredictable, while it is indeed more "predictable" in northern Sweden and Finland (and Norway), which is a little more typical of the polar climate.
And at last, the odds are much higher on winter, and the closer you are to the Arctic circle (or north pole), the more chances you'll get to see these. You have to take all of these in account, which means you'll most likely be stuck in snowy northern Sweden or Finland.
If you love skiing, or hiking with snowshoes, and don't mind not seeing the northern lights because you ran out of luck, go ahead.
This is the thing when you do nature/outdoor-centered tourism such as hiking or birdwatching, never expect everything as you wished for. Just take it as granted.

Iceland is beautiful and great to visit.
I live there for a while so here*'s my 2 cents.
Nice locals mostly but generaly not very initiative (you have to take the steps, they keep to themselves and let things happen as they happen)

>budget
It' s an exepensive country. And public transport doubly so.
Travelling in iceland in the winter to see northern lights is a bitch. Getting from place A to place B can be completely imposible from on day to the next. So finding a place where you can stay for a while and taking trips from there with a chance of it not happening that day is a Good options, but in winter you are nowhere without a (Good) car.

>Hostels
There are decent ones in reykavik but not as cheap as in other countries.
>food
Go to bonus, get Goods that lasts you a while with lots of nutrition (canned fish, travel read etc)
Fish in gereral is the cheapest option. Or buying far after experation Date.

>general take away
If you want to visit in winter to see northern lights find a place/bigger ish town to stay, rent a car and take trips but keep in mind everything might change.
Don't take stupid risks! If you get stuck somewhere there is rescue service but you might not be able to reach them before you freeze to death.
On a lighter note. You can check this website for northernlight predictions and general weather. Vedur.is

Its easier to visit in warmer months and gives you more hitchhike options as well (and easier camping).
Find work there (with housing) and take trips on that basis.

Or, get in contact with somebody in iceland (tinder gold?) and get their help travelling their country.

Or become a student in iceland! There is a small University in isafjordur where you can study a bunch of subjects.
There is an emediate social netwerk of studentes and locals. Options for relatively cheap student housing, partie and in the winter semester definitely northern lights!

Good luck

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2380532

Had great experiences with BlueCar. Theres usually a discount code online for them.
Although we booked in August 2021 right as things began opening up again. Cars where very limited (As they where globally).
Cost us £1500 for a Kia Rio for 2 weeks. That little thing was rugged as hell

The contactless pick up was excellent. Literally a small room next to their office, they email you a box number and a code and you pick the key up. Didnt even need to show them my license or insurance details. I may have verified that online before.

GET THE ADDITIONAL INSURANCE

Iceland is genuinely a 50/50 as to whether your rental car will get damaged every time you drive it. Be it from sand or dust damage, or idiots parking with the wind behind them and it bending the door frames due to the sheer force of the wind when opening a door.

Dont be an idiot who tries to drive a miniature Kia Rio, or Hyundai i10 on an F road, in winter. Youll just get stranded. You need 4x4 for most if not all F roads.

Driving in Iceland is honestly BASED. One of the best things I have ever done. The scenery is incredible. Obey the speed limits, even if they are slow, as the fines and tickets can be quite high.

You might be able to risk a little extra speed on the ring road when you can clearly see there is nobody about for miles, or the road is clear ahead.

Again, GET THE EXTRA INSURANCE. Its worth the piece of mind, even if dearer.
I left our car back in some state. Slight ding on the rear from an idiot american in a Range Rover reversing into me. The car was covered in mud and dust.

BlueCar didnt care, as I had the extra insurance.

Also, stopping at petrol stations for a hot dog and an ice cream can actually be a great way to save money. They are fairly inexpensive

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Fav Bathing / Lagoon Experience?

For us it was Sky Lagoon, followed by Lagurvatn then Blue Lagoon.

Its more expensive, but its vastly superior, and has less crowds due to limited bookings. Its worth paying the additional money to do the 7 step spa treatment. The views alone from inside the Suana looking out over the panoramic glass window is incredible, especially in bad weather.

You can be a bit cheeky, and in the crowds, you can go back into a few of the spa experience rooms a few times. I found if you carry a GoPro and ask them could you just pop in to get a quick photo they usually dont mind (Free publicity)

If you get the chance, make the trip to Lagurvatn Frontera. Its maybe a 30min detour from the Golden Circle, and youll experience proper Icelandic Leisure Pools outdoors. The ability to swim in the lake is also awesome too.

Blue Lagoon is cool, but its utterly hectic. Far too busy, but its spacious enough you can swim away from the crowds. Not exactly relaxing. The best thing is seeing the Icelandic Penis Police shout at the Americans in the shower rooms for not stripping off naked to wash themselves.

I believe there is a new "Forest Lagoon" opening in the North of Iceland soon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I plan only a little, usually I'll think what town I want to be at, and only one or two things I want to see that day. usually by writing into google: "attractions in X". But the way I see it, sightseeing isn't that important. If I want to see something, I could also just look up a picture online. The more important thing is to speak to people. Knowing languages is so important, and especially the international ones like English, Spanish, Russian, Arabic, Chinese. I would learn a bit of surface level politics and history. And just talk to people about what they think, how they live. People in a popular place like France or Spain don't give a rat's arse about tourists. But thats why I go to less touristy countries. People are interested and want to talk to you, about how the hell you wound up there.
When I went to Northern Ireland, I spoke to former IRA men. One of which was at Long Kesh prison. They told me how they joined the IRA, and how they smuggled things. And the next day I ended up meeting a warden at Long Kesh.
I've been Ukraine, got to see Kyiev and Lwow. In Lwow I struggled to understand their funny language, and my taxi driver gave me a bollocking for speaking Russian. Kyiev was lovely time though.
And now I've been in Moldova, and am chilling in Transnistria. I met a drunk local radio presenter, who was crying to me about the rise of fascism. Met a soldier who served in Georgia who took me around the city for a few roubles. On the bus I saw two Ukrainians shouting at eachother, one complaining about nazism, and the other saying she's full of shit.
Going to Nebraska next year. But thats more of a basic bitch holiday to see the rockies.

So far the only trips I've taken are road trips within the US (and a couple of other non-roadtrip domestic trips), sometimes I'm on the road for over a month and I still plan these autistically, pretty much day by day I know what I'll be doing and give myself a couple of options of where I might find a campsite each night. Sometimes I go a day or two ahead or behind schedule because of weather or other concerns but I always stick to my plan pretty closely. I'm mostly doing outdoor things, I give a copy of my plan to my dad so someone knows roughly if not exactly where I'll be.

I also have documents with just lists of things I want to do/see in other countries, every time I watch a travel blog or documentary or movie or book or anime or whatever and I see something I like I just add it to the respective list. My Japan document is like 4 pages long, many countries I have lists with dozens of entries also. I also have documents of specific features I like: for example I have one with just mountains I want to climb, one of waterfalls I'd like to see, etc. organized by how much I want to see/do them. It's incredibly autistic and I've never even left the country besides briefly at Niagara falls and Puerto Rico if that even counts. One day surely, haha

Neuquen is pretty much a big city now, isn't really that isolated, and has great landscapes.

Rio Negro is a bit more snowy, so naturally there's fewer urban areas, but still quite populated.

Chubut and Santa Cruz are pretty much full of industries and huge distances between every landmark. Would recommend it if you like isolation, snow and driving in it.

Otherwise, I would recommend Buenos Aires. You have the big city but there's also a lot of countryside to make your house there. About 100km you can choose exactly the amount of tranquility you're looking for depending on how far from tourist areas you want to go. Also, it's a lot cheaper to live there. Southern provinces are quite expensive. Pretty much the same as living in Europe.

Argie here, I'm seeing a handful of misconceptions about this place and the surrounding countries, so I'll clarify a couple things. Feel free to ask about anything else you have doubts about.

For one, this is not a "globohomo-free" country. Quite the opposite, in fact. Save for Uruguay, this is the most pozzed country in latin america. The government is more preoccuppied with preventing "hateful discourse" and forcing a butchered "inclusive" version of the spanish language than taking care of the one half of our population who's living below the poverty line. Not to mention most sides of the political spectrum haven't necessarily adopted but have at least accepted and allowed this shit to happen.
A second thing to note, I have no idea why you'd want to live in a country that has been edging at the brink of economic collapse for decades. Unless you feel like Lord Miles wasn't enough of a retard, I see no reason to leave your home to come live in a place like this. Also, you better like taxes, because you're gonna see a lot of them.
As for the surrounding countries, Uruguay has a great quality of life and everything outside Montevideo is fucking empty. Paraguay and Bolivia are alright, they're somehow less corrupt and more stable than we are. Chile is good, they recently elected a leftie, so people are panicking about them going the way of Venezuela and yours truly, but if you ask me, he seems like a very down-to-earth guy when compared to the usual, blind, retarded ideologues every other country gets when they elect a left-wing politician.

Ask away if you wanna know anything about the people, climate, living standards, etc. of any particular province/region.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2328122
Yup, government sponsored, too.

Back in the day when the country got its independence, our caudillos (pretty much spanish for "warlord") raided the south and genocided the shit out of every native tribes they could find. Somehow, this one survived and ended up becoming a what's essentially a cold war-style left-wing guerrilla terrorist group.

Once every few weeks, you'll hear of them terrorizing the people living in and around Neuquén, Río Negro, Chubut, and rarely Santa Cruz and southern Mendoza. They're always fighting with locals and "reclaiming" land belonging to the mapuche nation (look up "wallmapu" to see the extent of their larp).
The government, being your typical, run-of-the-mill leftie activist group, loves turning a blind eye to it. The last bit of news I remember hearing about is them intervening to take land away from the army to give it to one of these groups and the ensuing shitstorm that followed. Last year they spent like a whole month raiding the town of El Bolsón, to the point the locals got tired of nobody doing shit and took it in their own hands to literally ride on horses and hunt them down cowboy style. It was pretty surreal.

That said, it's not unlivable. Many popular tourist destinations are smack-dab in the middle of mapuche territory. Their numbers are far smaller here than in Chile, so the real problem lies on the other side of the Andes, it's just that here they have free reign to fuck with people.
If you see pic related, stay wary.

>how's the crime in the smaller cities and towns?
There used to be places here where there wasn't much to fear years ago, but the country is going downhill hard, so those places are starting to feel it.
That said, it will be less common than in the big cities. I won't say anywhere near zero, but it's harder to get away with shit when the place is small and everybody knows each other, lel. Town life is mostly chill, but far poorer depending on where you go (the north especially).
>Let's say a town of about 10k -- is there cartel bullshit going on there, or in any of the countryside?
Doubt it, most of the drug trafficking happens around/in the outskirts of the bigger cities (the exception being Rosario, where the WHOLE city is the argentinian equivalent of a mexican narco state, stay the fuck away).
>Do you feel safer in general in the smaller towns than you do in the cities?
Crime can always happen. You will be more "exposed" in small towns and you might be in trouble if you're hurt badly or feel unsafe at a particular moment in time, because small town hospitals have few resources and not as many policemen, while you'll be more prone to it in the cities but at least there are more resources/people to help you. "Safety" kinda depends on how much you can fend for yourself.
>How are the real estate prices there compared to La Tierra de las Hamburguesas?
Don't know much about that, actually, but I can tell you two things:
-Buenos Aires has been having problems reminiscent to that of London this year. Shit is too expensive and too small, so nobody wants it.
-As for the whole country in general, prices are just going up like everything else, so if you're planning to buy something, make sure you bring in as much foreign currency as you can so you don't have to start collecting Monopoly money that will have both lost its value and fallen short of the new price by the time you have it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2380992
I live there.
Tourist trap food: avoid anything around the Eiffel Tower, or anything extremely famous. Check google maps for pictures to give yourself an idea.

Migrants are bad but they basically all flock to the same few poor areas. Easy to avoid them in general and they are not touristy anyway. Basicaly avoid the north-east (around porte de la Chapelle, porte de la Villette) as these places host the infamous migrant tents.
Then you have neighborhoods with strong number of immigrants such as Château Rouge, Stalingrad, Gare du Nord, Gare de l’Est and Barbès-Rochechouart (not as bad as 20 years ago though, place got gentrified hard), and basically the eastern edge (porte de Montreuil etc). Avoid these, there’s nothing to see there maybe except Barbès since it’s not very far from Montmartre so you might have to go through there. Barbès during the day is not unsafe, just quite ugly to look at and watch out for pickpockets.

Many, many, many things to see, especially if you love history and art. Gustave Moreau museum, Henner museum, Bourdel museum, Petit Palais museum, for less known and not crowded museums.
Then you have the classic Louvre, Orsay museum, Orangerie museum, Versailles palace, Saint Chapelle, etc.

You don’t have to speak Italian. Almost everyone speaks English. It’s to the point they recognized an American accent in my Italian and would immediately switch to English. They can spot Americans or Italians who have lived in the US for a while because we pronounce Italian words like Mexicans. Restaurants are a problem if you’re traveling solo as is feeling moody and lonely. Italians have this whole meal time cultural thing that makes it suck for people who are alone. Donerbabs and fast food are your friends. Moody and lonely just comes with the isolation of traveling alone if you aren’t good at meeting people. Keep busy looking at things. There’s a lot to see. Avoid nogs, rags, and zingari. You have to do Rome due to the amount of historical things to look at, but avoid nogs at all costs in that city and limit your time in the train station…just get in and get out. Rome is chaotic and very much a big city and tourist trap. Florence is going to be much better, much more laid back, with friendlier people. Pisa is a university town. Some of the smaller cities in the north are surprisingly pleasant. Genoa, Turin, etc. Bologna has been gentrified a lot. You can even walk Bolognina after dark these days even if the streets are surprisingly empty by 9 pm for an Italian city. The further south you go the more dysfunctional it gets but not in a dangerous way. That’s just northern stereotypes about the subhuman terrone (mostly true, but they are just dumb and lazy, not dangerous). Hotels will suck by American standards, even compared to a Holiday Inn express, so unless you want to know how to say Norman Bates in Italian it’s worth the money to go up a star or two. Inflation has hit hard and things are expensive there now. Be prepared for that. You get a mixture of competent and lazy as shit with Italians. If they don’t volunteer to do something then expect to just have to deal with it not being done.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2379697
Florence will be good. They do free entry to Boboli gardens on some Sundays. The monastery or whatever up the hill has much better city views than the meme Piazzale Michelangelo. The kiosk near SMN across from the Burger King has good pork or cow intestine sandwiches. There is a nice cheap (for Italy) pizzeria up Nazionale just past the gelato place on the corner. Don’t waste money on the pajeet leather touts. There are a couple of legit store fronts run by Italians for that. Spend some time on the right bank of the Arno. Get up early and hit the big tourist sites in Rome before the crowds get there and then just wander. Try to go into every church you see if you’re into that sort of art. They are free to get into. There are also a bunch of meme fountains and shit. You have to pay to get into a lot of the historical sites. Near the big ugly TV screen on Cavour go down the stair case with the mural and you’ll find a bunch of narrow streets with restaurants and stuff. Use the Republicca metro station passageways to cross the street around that big clusterfuck instead of braving the crosswalks. Buchetto is a good sandwich place on Viminale. Borghese is a good park. Wander through Ludovisi and the area west of Porta Pia outside of the walls. If you go north just before Porta Pia inside the old walls you’ll find a small communist neighborhood with a lot of left wing nose ringed teenagers loitering around to try to sex up. Also they can be found loitering outside the old walls south of Pia Porta. The age of consent in Italy is 15. Also most Italian women stink and are ugly. Enjoy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Nogs hang around the tourist sites and will act like they are going to give you a high five, then grab your arm and try to tie a string bracelet to it and demand that you pay for it. Just scowl at them and keep walking. If they do force a bracelet on you, just steal it without paying. They’ll ooga booga a bit but they are there illegally and don’t want police attention so they’ll fuck off. You’ll get white people trying to get you to sign petitions. Just scowl, pretend you don’t speak English, say something in Russian, and keep walking. If it’s an attractive woman you can use the opportunity to try to sex her up (they are Italians usually, not slavs or zingari) but don’t sign and don’t give money. They aren’t pushy, and I’m not sure if they are real petitions or just a scam but I don’t care either way. Zingari you just stare at like you want them dead and keep moving. Make sure they know you hate them. They are subhuman scum. Arabs and pajeets will be minding their own business except for the rags around Termini who might try to pickpocket. Pickpockets are only a problem in train stations or if you get into a heavy crowd in a major tourist area. It’s gotten a lot better in Rome lately. The zingari will send little kids to do it because they can’t be jailed so be prepared to kick an 8 year old in the face if necessary. Don’t feel bad. They aren’t human and the police don’t really care what you do to them. Overall it’s not nearly as bad as it used to be, though.

Rome has some unwritten traffic and pedestrian rules. Watch the Italians, not the tourists, around you and do what they do when crossing streets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I often travel solo. I just came back from a self-driving trip in the Netherlands.

>dining alone
Nobody gives a fuck. If you really are scared to look strange for some dumb reason, go to a pub that serves food, and eat food at the counter. This is what I usually do when the place seems crowded.
Bonus: talk to the barman. You’ll learn a lot about local things.

>fumbling to speak with any people
Learn some basic words and sentences you midwit. If the place is english-friendly, then just talk normally, if not, just limit yourself to basic sentences and words. Learn some (“can I eat here”, “water”, etc), it takes a few minutes.

>not enjoying the trip at all and feeling lonely and moody
That’s up to you.

That’s probably a misperception. Florence is way more chill than Milano. Florence has a lot of pajeets, some very dark skinned and chimp like, but fewer arabs and dark black niggers from Africa. There are a lot of gook tourists, though. If you’re in Italy you have to do Rome just for the history. You’ll get about 3 hours to sit and relax if you take the regional from SMN to Termini. Usually no changes on that route but it’ll drop you on the east platforms in Termini. You can also take a low stress day just to wander around the parks and hang out in Rome. Borghese is good…not crowded and in a leafy part of the city so you won’t see a single black face up that way. Don’t feel pressured to see everything there is to see in Rome because you physically can’t…it’s too much. Just hit the high points and whatever else you stumble across.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2373361
Anywhere that has a decent amount of hostels will be good. If a country doesn't have hostels then that's a pretty good indicator that it's a "hard" country to travel in. So type a country on booking dot com then filter for hostels only and see how many options there are.

However, in a more general sense, I think it's simply a good idea to go places that aren't particularly far away from you because that just makes your first time a little nicer and easier. Spending 25 hours to get there and then spending 25 hours to get back is ok, but when you were only there for 15 days it's a bit shit. I know you said you don't want latin america, but somewhere like Belize, Costa Rica etc. would probably be good (not that I know much about those countries), they're nearby, I imagine visa wouldn't be too hard for you as a US citizen and they're different enough culturally that it will be an interesting experience. Booking has a lot of options for hostels in costa rica and panama which tells me that they're good countries for doing this in.

Hostels are a good general tip as well, since if you stay in one you will meet people who can give you inspiration on where to go, or meet people to eat with or go party with etc. A lot of people are scared of staying in shared accommodation or they think only stoner hippies use it, but that's far from the truth, I'd recommend at least trying a few hostels if you're unsure about them. Travelling alone doesn't necessarily mean being alone.

posts.com:
The five ex-Soviet "Stans" aren't as much talked about as other destinations despite offering a lot to visitors.
I have lived and travelled through them, so let me give you an overview in case you're interested.

posts.name: Kazakhstan
posts.com:
The biggest of five countries and also the country with subjectively the least number of obvious tourist attractions.
What makes up for it is the sheer size of the country, you can spend days going across by train and experience the diversity of landscapes from snow-capped mountains, empty steppe to plain old desert.

The big split is between North and South, with the less-visited North featuring the Dubai-esque capital Astana (formerly Nur-Sultan, formerly Astana) and the "Russian" provinces and the Karaganda desert, the South having multiple historical cities dotted along the border.

Most people will visit Almaty, the most successful example of a modernised Soviet city and also the only place where you can eat at western fast-food chains that aren't KFC for a change.
Near Almaty you can find a lot of mountainous nature such as the Big Almaty Lake (pic related), valleys and nature parks towards China but also a glimpse into China at the Khorgos Special Economic Zone where duty is charged by the kilo.
Almaty and Bishkek in Kyrgyzstan are 4 hours and about 10 dollars apart by car, you can easily fly into either city and reach the other on the same day.

A underrated place is the South-West: On the way from or to Uzbekistan you can make a detour for a day trip to newly-renovated Turkestan and Taraz is also worth stopping over for a couple hours.
The highway between Almaty and Shymkent is a racetrack, especially at night, so if you want to keep your nerves just use one of the frequent trains.

Western Kazakhstan is partially located in Europe and can be used as a starting point towards the Caucasus and Russia by low-cost carrier and frequent overnight trains.
On the way you will pass Baikonur, sadly only legally accessible through overpriced tours, launches can be seen from outside, sneaking in can be risky, especially in the current political climate.

posts.name: Kyrgyzstan
posts.com:
The "Switzerland of Central Asia" has the most liberal visa regime, most Westerners will be able to stay for 60 days without any visa or other bureaucratic hurdles.

Everybody will pass through Bishkek, the poorer, more "Soviet" cousin of Almaty, especially if you need a visa for any neighbouring country.
The city itself can be visited in a day, two if you're interested in bazars, Alamedin, Dordoi and Osh bazar being the ones recommended for a comprehensive experience.
The city may be boring to visit but is very comfortable to live due to low price levels and everything a second world dweller being in walking distance.

The main draw of Kyrgyzstan is the nature, be it the surprisingly good ski resort near Karakol, the never-freezing Issyk-Kul, the countless valleys featuring yurts and hot springs, the mountain passes towards the South and the changed Kyrgyz part of the Fergana valley.
If you are fine with not being spoken to in English you can get nature excursions for low, be it guided hikes, ski transfers to yurt stays with optional horse riding.
Try to get excursions with meals prepared by locals, during summer you will usually get loads of fresh vegetables and fruits to complement the meat-laden main dishes.

posts.name: Tajikistan
posts.com:
The non-Turk outlier of the region that is heavily influenced by Persian culture has become more open recently, with most westerners being able to enter visa-free for 30 days.
You still need to get a separate permit to visit the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonmous Oblast, but you should be able to get it on the way in Dushanbe.

Despite being the poorest country (salary-wise), as a tourist you end up spending more money than in neighbouring Kyrgyzstan, be it on transport, accommodation or imported goods.

Tajikistan has some dishes that you cannot find in the surrounding countries, a blessing if you have been in rural areas for a while and are getting tired of plov, samsas and noodles.
Many expats say that Dushanbe feels a bit like Pyongyang, with police checking beards and headwear to prevent extremism from taking root and the limited number of places to go after work where you will end up meeting the same people anyway.

If you're in Tashkent for more than two days and getting bored you can do an overnight trip to Khujand across the border to see what the city would have looked like before the reconstructions.

Because of the border conflict and other border closures you will not be able to enter Kyrgyzstan without taking a detour via Uzbekistan, easy to do from Khujand or Dushanbe, more annoying when you're deep in the GBAO.

posts.name: Turkmenistan
posts.com:
There are two way to see Turkmenistan, the expensive and comprehensive way using a North Korea style tour with a guide and driver or by rushing through the country on a transit visa between Iran and Uzbekistan.
If on a tour everything will be taken care of, just pay the amount requested and enjoy the ride.
If you successfully managed to get a transit visa then you will spend your time and cash moving between towns in trains and shared taxis with locals, haggling with hotels for low rates, bribing officials with dollars and cigarettes (which seem to have become more and more valuable in the last year, an open pack can save you queues and inspections without much suspicion.

The most popular transit visa route is between Urgench/Khiva and Mashad, within three days you can see unique nature (pic related), a historical city and the shiny marble capital.

posts.name: Uzbekistan
posts.com:
In the "Big Three" cities of Samarkand/Bukhara/Khiva you will find the closes to mass tourism, with European boomers spending their retirement money on souvenirs to bring back to their boomer friends.
Still, it's nowhere near the levels of any European tourist city, even at the most popular sites you can just wait five minutes and you'll be only be sharing it with domestic tourists and local touts.

While the Big Three are what draw the most people, on a longer visit you may want to check out more nature-based destinations such as Karakalpakstan, site of what used to be the Aral Sea or the Fergana Valley where the above-mentiond souvenirs are actually made.

Moving between regions can be done by train or by domestic flight via Tashkent.
While the flights are comfortable and not too expensive, you can save money and experience authentic Uzbekistan by taking an overnight train, especially if you book third class (platzkart). If you find out that the experience is too authentic for you, you can easily bribe the conductor to find you a private compartment for about 10 to 15 dollars.

While Tashkent might be your entry point, you will quickly find out that it's a fairly boring city, especially the nightlife when compared to Almaty and Bishkek.
Sadly for the inclined tourist there are less and less Soviet-era buildings left untouched in Tashkent, but a simple trip to any neighbouring country will satisfy your cravings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What you definitely need are some skills reading Cyrillic, even in countries that formally switched to Roman characters.
With only English you won't get as far somebody who speaks just even basic Russian, English services are generally available but come at a premium.
Just using some basic greetings in the respective local languages will usually be met with enthusiasm, even if you then continue in Russian or pidgin English-Russian.

Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan are the two countries where you won't stand out as a white Westerner due to the high number of ethnic Russians, even at bazars you will get the same treatment as locals, at least until you open your mouth. Usually, this will work to your advantage, but be prepared to be talked to in Rapid Russian.

The region has a reputation of being dangerous, mostly due to the proximity to Afghanistan, but as a tourist the biggest risk you'll face is road traffic, some taxi rides will make even the most euphoric atheist pray for a safe journey.

In most cities you can save yourself a lot of trouble by installing the Yandex Taxi app, the local equivalent to Uber. Even just showing the app prices will give you stronger hand while haggling, never use a metered taxi without fixating a price first, it's an invitation to get ripped off.

Tourist SIM cards are available in every country, the easiest being in Kyrgyzstan where they'll just hand them out for free at busy border crossings, the most expensive being in Turkmenistan (and you may not be able to use shitpost on /int/), see the ever-useful Prepaid SIM Card Wiki for more details.

The best English internet site for this region is Caravanistan, some of the articles may become outdated but the forum will usually have the relevant updates.
I'll check this thread for questions and try to answer until this thread dies, so ask away!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>That being said, what’s the best time of the year to visit them?
You can visit all year around, but each region has its "best" season.
The desert parts of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and the whole of Turkmenistan are best visited in spring and autumn because it can get hot in summer, easily more than 40°C for days, although dry heat, so more bearable than similar humid destinations.
The mountain parts of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan have their main season in summer when you can hike everywhere and all the summer facilities are open. In winter there are fewer places where you can go skiing and winter hiking, but in early spring and late autumn you'll find many places closed.
TL;DR: summer/winter for mountains, spring/autumn for the rest

>My russian is very very basic, will I survive?
Little Russian is already better than no Russian.
Learn some useful common phrases (e.g. Pimsleur Russian) and download an offline translator. Make sure that you have a Russian keyboard enabled in case somebody wants to translate to English.
I personally make sure to write down any amounts negotiated (especially taxi fares) on paper or on my phone and show them to prevent and misunderstandings or "misunderstandings" (i.e. scams).

>Lastly, what’s that flag chart?
It's the flags of the five countries crossed with each other!
You can see the original flags on the diagonal from top left to bottom right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>What would be the best order or “loop” to visit the stans?
If you have visa-free access to Uzbekistan I'd pass through there multiple times because you can get to all the other countries from there.
The KG-TJ border is closed and will likely remain closed for the time being, so Tajikistan is pretty much only accessible from Uzbekistan.
Having said that it's all a matter of preference and (time) budget.
If Turkmenistan opens (to how it used to be in 2019) I would enter from Iran on a transit visa via the Mashad-Ashgabat-Khiva route because that way you won't have to worry about carrying large amounts of cash afterwards.
From there I'd do the "Big Three" Khiva->Bukhara->Samarkand before crossing the border to Panjakent (TJ), going down to Dushanbe, the base for planning any activities in the GBAO.
The return from Dushanbe would be via Khujand to Tashkent, if you don't want to do the Anzob twice, you can also go via Termez, possible even by train.
From Tashkent you can either go North to see more desert/steppe in Kazakhstan or East to the Fergana valley, ending up in Osh (KG).
From there you can do the 10-hour ride to Bishkek, stopping over in Toktogul for a night if you want.
In Northern Kyrgyzstan, you will very likely spend some time in Issyk-Kul, both on the lake and the surrounding mountains, stopping over in Karakol before heading towards Almaty, easily reached via Bishkek, the more adventurous and scenic path via the Karakara valley.
From Almaty you can go West to Taraz/Shymkent/Turkestan for the Silk Road sights or North to Karaganda and Astana (not much to see but surprisingly cool during summer due it being very windy).

Obviously this is a very packed itinerary for a two-months, so you want to drop destinations and flesh out your stay at others.
You can do 4 out of 5 countries in less than 24 hours (by bus and taxi between Khujand TJ and Bishkek KG), but that's neither relaxing nor recommended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>Where would you spend most of your time?
It really depends on what you like:
Like mountains? Then you'll have the best time in Kyrgyzstan where you can spend months in the mountains if you desire.
Like history that isn't just rock carvings and shards? You'll be best served with Uzbekistan, both the "Big Three" and smaller destinations like the countless fortresses in the desert.

All countries but Turkmenistan give you ample time to visit and visa runs can be had for cheap.

It is really easy to go country collecting (my passport has pages and pages filled with entry and exit stamps due to extended weekend trips), but in the end you do not want to rush from one place to the next because of a tight itinerary.
Yes, you can visit Khiva/Bukhara in one day, but strolling through town in the late evening or early morning with nobody else in sight is something you can only do if you spend a night or two there.
The same can be said about chilling on the shores of Issyk-Kul or spending a lazy day in a yurt camp reading a book while listening to nature.

Anyway, let me know if you want to know more about a place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Food wise, how’s the food?
There's a reason why the region isn't a gourmet travel destination: The local dishes aren't much to write home about.
You'll have a lot of meat and grease and many dishes will start to feel similar after being here for some time.
The good thing is that the Soviet time brought foreign dishes that are now a staples of the local diet everywhere.
One of them are salads influenced by ethnic Koreans, available in all bazaars, most restaurants, delicatessen and supermarkets.
On a regular day, at least one of my meals contains whatever kind of salad I feel like that day. On bazaars they're usually home-made, sold by middle-aged women, most of them will let you try before buying, use that opportunity to sample, same applies for confectionery sold there.
I personally avoid "Pizza&Sushi" places, most of them don't do either right. Bigger cities have both proper pizzerias and sushi bars if you want to mix things up a little.

People are very proud of their bread (pic related), try to spot the differences between regions.
Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan have surprisingly good dairy products, just be aware that they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West.
Try whatever produce is in season, local fruits and vegetables are usually very tasty and fresh due to short supply chains. Again, they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West, probably because the local agriculture is less developed and therefore uses fewer modern preservatives.

If you're taking the train, take some vegetables, fruits and bread to share because the locals love to feed foreigners and see their reactions to local food and it's nice to be able to share as well.
Trains always have hot water, so instant noodles and mashed potatoes will be a safe backup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>What I can’t absolutely miss?
Try the "signature dishes" of the region like plov, lagman, beshparmak, manty, samsa.
Eat the ones you like again, preferably at small places, the shorter the menu, the better the dishes.

In Kyrgyzstan, especially in Issyk-Kul you have to try Ashlan-Fu (pic related), a Chinese-style cold noodle soup with vinegar (works very well for hangovers).
In Tajikistan you have to try Kurutob, a salad made from bread that for some reason you can't find in the neighbouring countries.
Don't forget about local minorities: Uyghurs and Dungans have some nice dishes, as have the ethnic Koreans that operate the Korean restaurants found in every bigger city.

If it's your first trip to the former USSR then you should definitely try what the other republics have to offer, be it Moldovan/Georgian/Azeri wine, Russian and Georgian cuisine or just plain old Ukrainian sweets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Also, is there a sim card that works in all of them?
It's cheaper and less hassle to buy a SIM card in each country than to see what roaming offers are available.
Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan can be annoying by requiring a hardware registration if you want to use a local SIM card for more than a month.
You can avoid that by roaming using a Kyrgyz SIM card, but that's too much of a hassle unless you're living in Kyrgyzstan, especially since you'll need to figure out the offers and how to top up from abroad if needed.
Roaming from abroad is usually expensive, the least expensive place for Europeans being Kazakhstan, in the rest of the region a local SIM card reigns supreme.
If you're just passing through Turkmenistan then you shouldn't waste your time hunting for a SIM card, if you're on a tour then your guide will be able to help you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370901
You're going to be spending some money - a budget tour of 4 days and 3 nights from a Western agency runs about 1000 dollars, for an additional 400 dollars you'll get 8 nights and 9 days in the country.
Obviously some local tour operator might be able to shave off some dollars from the quoted prices above, but most of the costs are set by the Turkmen government, so no getting around that.
This is the major reason why transit visa runs through the country are popular, you save money and have more (limited) freedom to choose your way through the country.

Any well-stocked tour agency can book you a tour to Turkmenistan, they all need to cooperate with some companies within the country that can issue the relevant invitation letters.
Have a look on the internet what interests you and get quotes from different companies, no need to pay more for the same service.
Caravanistan might start up their middleman services once the country opens and they get confirmations of things running again.

The best place to buy anything vehicle-related would be Almaty, with Bishkek (Dordoi auto-bazaar) being a close second, Tajikistan (Dushanbe) being a distant third.
Uzbekistan limits the import of cars and related goods, hence the omnipresent domestic Daewoos and Chevrolets and Turkmenistan is a trade nightmare.

A cheaper method would be to look in various expat groups of the region for people selling their bike or even posting that you're looking to buy one, same applies for the Caravanistan forums.

This is something you have to consider, you can avoid most of this by buying from fellow travellers heading back home (e.g. via Caravanistan or social media) or by using one of the traders recommended by people.
They will charge you for their services but the money you pay them is a pittance compared to the annoyances they prevent in terms of scams and registration issues.
For bureaucracy in general, it is worth to go with a trusted local, as they know when to call bluffs and when it is appropriate to expedite the process with a small cash gift.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2376275
Yes, the road between Dushanbe and Khujand is the major road of Tajikistan, so they go through great pains to keep it open the whole year.
On the way you'll pass through the infamous Anzob tunnel, nicknamed "the tunnel of death" because it was operating for ten year while unfinished, but since about 2016 this is not the case any more, now it's just another long tunnel with the usual traffic dangers present in the region.

If you want to be absolutely sure to keep to your schedule you can plan to go via Termez/Samarkand/Oybek in Uzbekistan, their roads and rails are open all year round without major problems.

The people in the region are conservative and there's a big gap between rural and city people.
In the countryside, "dating" will consist of convincing the village elders that you're a suitable groom, a very difficult task unless you have spent significant time there and have immersed in the local language and culture.
In cities you'll face the typical dating pattern found in more conservative countries: The man leads the date and pays for everything and the woman tries to look her best.
Many young locals do know some English but are hesitant to speak, with many of them becoming quite fluent speakers once they're drunk.
Even women with a liberal worldview are sexually conservative and like to show off their housewife skills by wanting to feed you with food they cook, showing off their bargaining skills or even offering to fix the shirt you tore during your date.
You will also quickly get to know her brothers/cousins/friends who will invite you to their activities consisting of drinking, smoking and all kinds of sports and physical activities to judge you for themselves.
Speaking Russian and/or the local language will definitely help your chances in all stages of the process.

i assume the points on the map are stops you are making?
Are all destinations locked in or just a general loop?
What sort of things do you have planned to do?
What classic europe trip stuff are you not into?
What types of things do you think you're into

Is Zurich a planned stop?
Because a cool route from Munich is south route to Innsbruk Austria, to Italy thru Dolomite mountains - Bolzano (Nearby bressanone, ortisei, merano - famous parks for ex puez odle) to Trento, along Lake Garda, to Verona (one of my fav cities).
From Verona (this could also be connected on your Zurich to Milan route) is a transverse northern italy trainline.
Venice - Padua - Vicenza - Verona - Pescheria Del Garda - Brescia - Bergamo - Milan - Turin. Italians autisitcally hate the northern cities but as a foreigner i thought they were pretty comfy but as with everywhere it is usually cooler outside the city.
The italian northern lakes are very popular so if you are going from zurich to genoa as on the map - you're passing near lake lugano between lake maggiore and lake como, both have beautiful towns, but summer in italy famous spots will have tourists naturally. other northern lakes as mentioned garda but the lower tier ones are beautiful too like iseo or orta
Are you going to Genoa area or were just thinking to travel along the riviera all the way to barcelona? South of milan is Pavia - old city with a few landmarks.
other direction there is cinque terre but will be crowded. There are many popular tourist towns on italian riviera, Portofino is a fancy one.
Like every region there are tiny beautiful towns, like Dolceacqua or Apricale - but is it worth the time getting there on a tight schedule with public transport? depends if you are taking a break or seek those things.
Drive italian riviera to french riviera is nice.
In france before Nice there are towns of Menton, Eze. This area has the roads called Les Trois Corniches

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
From Germany, There is the Romantic Road - in Bavaria, it is a tourist track that all the towns kind of have comfy romantic architecture but if you were coming from Prague - Nuremberg or Regensburg have good medeival town centres. A bit further off route there is wurzburg too. Rothenburg ob der Taber is probably super popular tourist spot but it was cool.

If you got to Munich area - for a detour, Salzburg was pretty comfy, there is also the austrian lake district outside salzburg most famous town is hallstadt,
Also in that direction there is Chiemsee - a lake in germany has an unfinished 1800s palace on an island. There is hitler's eagles nest hideout too.
South of munich there are touristy bavarian mountain towns at the foot of the mountains like zugspitze you could get cable car up that.
Near the town of Fussen there is the Neuschwanstein Castle
On your map you go near Lindau before going into switzerland -is an island town.

If you drive through french riviera towards marseille, there are the famous fancy towns like cannes and saint tropez but traffic might be congested by them but inland in that area is also beautiful. and if you are looking to see beautiful south french coast, just before marseille are the Calanques of Marseille. Verdon national park has a nice canyon river. If you look in the countryside of any place you'll find weird things like Malpasset Dam - a collapsed dam disaster, maybe not interesting to everyone but if i was in the neighborhood itd be cool.
Towns like Arles, Orange, Nimes have a large intact roman structure or two. Avignon famous for the french pope + its bridge song. Pont Du Gard aqueduct.
In June Provence lavender fields start to blum - Plateau de Valensole is a famous region. They also have sunflowers. There are too many villages in every region of france that if you were on a road trip could be worth passing through. some cool looking ones are like Moustiers-Sainte-Marie, Gordes, Roussillon, Les Baux-de-Provence

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Carcassonne is a famous tourist spot - the classic fairytale castle vibe has been recreated here i think in 1800s reconsturction.

Millau is like one of the largest bridges in the world or something.

Albi has a neat history - grand cathedral built to establish catholic presence, there was another sect of christianity Cathars that were put down centred in Albi

Going into Spain, Girona is a medieval town that is famous as a foodie destination, has some film+tv shoots there.
Castellfollit de la Roca is a cool looking village in the country, and Besalú
North of Barcelona there is Montserrat monestary in the mountian
Tarragona has roman amphitheatre, and an aquaduct

Going thru middle of switzerlnd, Interlaken is the most famous area. As mentioned Lauterbrunnen - it is like fairytale land with high waterflls off the mountains. Grindelwald also famous. gelmerbahn looks neat to try - there are a lot of cogwheel trains for steep mountains in switzerland.
Famous ski destinations are nice in summer too - like Zermatt (Matterhorn) is an alpine town that has no civilian traffic, you have to train into town.
A bit in the wrong direction but Stelvio Pass road into italy is quite famous.
Valle Verzasca is sometimes clickbait called Maldives of Milan - north of Locarno, the crystal blue river, there is a famous bridge ponte dei salti

Pray you dont get grenades thrown at you or outright fucked with as its a no-go zone for police.

France and it's stops should be the biggest time spender on your trip. Cut out Spain and do north Italy proper instead or cut out Italy and do north Spain properly rather than rushing it. Poland is a meme stop with this itinerary, you should cut from Prague back home through Germany.

2 days max.
Get the Athens multi pass so you can see all the 5 major exhibitions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2380189
It’s >>2380162 replying here here.

For me, the complete opposite.

Athens was the first place I ever solo travelled to. I’d never been somewhere as clumsily busy, as noisy and polluted, yet so romantic, soulful and beautiful.

I had my days exploring odd, rough and interesting neighbourhoods. Where one end of the street would have commie squatters partying throughout the week and the other side, groups of riot police ready to go with submachine guns in hand and full combat gear at all hours of the day and night. All whilst old people would sit by on another side playing checkers and enjoy the Greek sun watching it all pass by.

I’d go out to a few clubs and bars, all of which were electric, absolutely rammed full of people. I walked back to my hotel on the other side of the city with no phone one night, exploring old winding streets and passages in the warm Greek summer night breeze, passing by groups of rabid looking homeless schizos, old bookshops still open, a group of dancing women and a man getting violently beaten by Greek police dressed head to toe in black combat gear. My hotel was at the top of a hill, I looked back and saw the Acropolis lit up, shining in the night so beautifully against the backdrop of the city. Out of all of the worlds monuments I’ve seen, the Acropolis at night is easily one of the most beautiful.

The next day I took a bus to the beach, and felt like I was transported to a completely different place altogether. Pristine white sand, clear water, it was incredible.

Honestly, I rate Athens 10/10, if you want somewhere more modern, metropolitan or sanitised there are a million other places.

Who visits every attraction?

I went to Washington DC last year. To visit all those I would imagine it would take well over a week, rushing through museums and racing through monuments and very careful planning, plus skipping meals. But you will get fatigued of visit museums and monuments after 2-3 days like a tourist robot doing what other tourist robots do and pretending to be cultured and caring about museum and attractions. Washington DC has some cool parks closeby I would recommend checking one or two out to break up the monotony of gawking at buildings, monuments and going to museums.

A shocking number of those museums require you to actually book a ticket in advance of your visit. I think the Spy Museum which I definitely wanted to visit fell under that category. I think the African American museum also did.

If you are not there with a car, I would recommend to rent the bikes they have, their equivalent of NYC's Citibike, I forgot what they call their network. There are stations near every major monument and it will save so much time compared to walking and so much money compared to cabs or renting a car.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2378955

For future reference OP, a lot of the German insurers will offer global health coverage (Auslandskrankenversicherung) for around €10-20 a year as an add-on. You can also often add travel insurance (Reiseversicherung) to your home insurance for like a euro a month in some cases. There's no need to buy separate policies each time you go abroad as in the UK and it works out a lot cheaper too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2380589

Just to clarify, in Germany these are two separate kinds of insurance. Auslandskrankenversicherung covers health stuff, Reiseversicherung covers flight cancellations etc. The first one is always a must, the second I'd only get for certain kinds of trips.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2380593

Another tip, the travel health insurance policies you sometimes get with German credit cards are usually dogshit as they usually don't cover a lot of important things like medical evacuation. Don't rely on them, always get proper global cover.

Meth is still the drug of choice here as it allows people to work longer hours spend less on food. A small bag of that (punta) is like 200-500 pesos depending and it will keep you up all day so its afforable to the working man.

Weed is available, as it grows wild in the Philippines, but I would proceed with caution especially if your a fresh off the plane tourist and you don't know anybody. DO NOT trust people on the street trying to sell you shit......best case scenario, they'll sell you a half gram of dirt weed for 20-30 dollars, medium case scenario they'll run off with the money, worst case they'll try to set your ass up

Another thing to consider if you do manage to score some weed is where are you gonna smoke it? Most likely your gonna be staying in a hotel or condo, and many of those are non smoking. Forget about smoking on the street.....Filipinos are notoriously NOSEY and will inquire as to what your doing at any and all times. Even weak bud.... it stinks and .the smell wafts and lingers..... and theirs always at least 38 guards in any given hotel or condo snooping around. I really would only suggest smoking if you had a private house that your gonna be staying in for a while so you can remove the smell before you move out

Lastly , if you do ever get involved in drugs here, even if it just smoking pot for recreation NEVER EVER EVER tell anyone you use drugs. You keep that between whoever you buy it from and yourself. Talisay/Minglanilla: These are suburbs of Cebu city. You'll be able to find larger homes for rent here at reasonable rates. 30-35k (560$-700$) will get you quite a nice home. Talisay also has a nice plaza thats kino at night...they call it TPARK in the local lingo...LOTS of chickens running around.....and when I say chicken I mean horny young women between the ages of 18-22

Naga/San Fernando: I have no idea what goes on here. Its a suburb of a surburb, I never went up into every mountain parts of these neighborhoods , but its proabably just sarisari stores, vulcanizing shops, karoke machines, and crowing roosters.They also have a really big cement plant, so if your into heavy industry instead of cooming you can go look at dudes make cement. The only place I can recommend here is blueridges mountain resort. Rooms are 2k, but it has a kino view of the mountainside and a nice pool. Do bring a date and preferrebaly your own transportation though....its a trek up that mountain for sure.

CarCar: This is the end of the suburbs of suburbs, and the start of the province proper. The have a roundabout in their plaza, and you have the option of going right, or continuing straight. For the purpose of this guide we will continue straight heading south along the coastal road

Sibonga: Nothing to see here. They have a wet market if you are staying in a nearby resort and want to grill some meats.

Argao: Check out mahayahay beach if you're on a budget, the maayo hotel if your on a medium budget, or panorama de argao for a kino view of the mountains and more luxurious hotel experience

Dalaguete: They have a beach that I would classify as "MEHHH". Osmena peak is nice little mountain trek everyone knows, kino views. One of the presidents of the Philippines actually crached his plane there, so go look at some history you non-coomers.

Alcoy: Tingko beach is kino, do visit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2368484
Boljoon: Bunch of resorts along the coast. Also has a trekking trail/waterfall.....dayhag falls. If you go to the falls do ask a Kuya to guide you there as it's easy to get lost because the cell phone signal will drop that far into the interior of the island, rendering your google maps or whatever useless. The roads are shitty going up there so either be a more experienced motorcycle driver or let kuya drive and backride.

Oslob: Ahhhhh the famous Oslob. Every tourist tout will try to get you to go here. You can swim with some whale sharks for 1k pesos, locals are 500 pesos......photographs will be 500 pesos. You will see alot of boomers with their 20 year gfs here. It's the most basic bitch tourist attraction in the whole of Cebu. Tumalog falls is also nice, do visit there. IF you like spanish colonial history, you can go look at the old church complex, and if your a cubabro you can reminisce on the time that "WE WUZ KANGZ". DO check out Sumilon island as well, just off the coast of oslob.

Santander: Most southern part of Cebu island. Nothing really of note here except a boat that can transport you to Siquijor......you might be able to get a boat to Dumaguete here as well. Here we will loop around the start heading north along the western coast of Cebu.

Samboan: They have about 4 different treks/waterfall here. Agunid, Binalayan, balay sawa, and Dao. All of them are easy treks, except for Dao. I wouldn't recommend Dao if your a fatfuck, or if you're with older people, its a true jungle trek but the falls are kino.

>>2368488
Ginatilan: Inambakan is one of my favorite falls in Cebu, truly beautiful. Kabutongan falls is also in this town, but I would classify it as "MEHH"

Malabuyoc: Nothing really of note here. Handigan falls is a trekking area, you can have a jungle picnic with your flip waifu here.

Alegria: 3 waterfalls here. Cambais, Cangkalanog, Montpieller. Again, you better be a good navigator, motorcycle driver, and be able to talk bisaya if you want to get to these. I would recommend getting a kuya at the plaza to guide you, the roads can be treacherous and unmarked on google maps.

Badian: This is home to the famous Kawasan falls, the runner up for most basic bitch tourist attraction in Cebu. Every tout will recommend you this. You will see groups of Asian tourists walking around with life vests and helmets, touts will harasss you almost non stop, and you'll hardly be able to walk or enjoy the view because of the crowds. It's the only place I've ever seen a fucking traffic jam at a waterfall I'm being dead ass serious. Lambug beach is also located here, and is probably one of the best public beaches in Cebu.....white sand, blue water, not rocky, accommodation on the beach etc. Kansanto springs is a more local spot where you can have a picnic and a cold swim.

Moalboal: This is a nice beach town. Lots of foreigners here. Split between 2 beaches....White Beach and Panagsama. White beach is more suitable to swimming as its less rocky, but you'll have less choice of accomidation and they will be of lower quality. Panagsama beach is a bit more rocky, but they have better accommodation/food choices there. It's one of the few places in the province that has some semblance of a nightlife. Chili bar is nice during sunset, and they used to have a disco that had lots of beautiful women in there, both pinay and foreign, but I'm not sure if it survived the pandemic. I went there recently but it was during a weekday and it was closed, but they might open the disco on weekends
