posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Cubabro here sharing some more knowledge. Today's topic is MALLS. I know I know.....many of you despise malls because you're coming from America/Europe/Australia and the malls there are dead at best, and souless centers of consumerism at worst...but hear me out. Malls in the Philippines serve many functions. MOST (not all.....all you conyo Filipinos shut the fuck up, sit down and listen) Filipinos can't actually afford anything in the larger malls. They go there because it's one of the few places they can get free aircon/wifi, people watch, window shop, variety of foods etc. They are some of the cleanest and best maintained places in the Philippines. This being said, these are some of the most densely populated places, and if your mission is hunting for a girl/boy/ladyboy WHATEVER, these are great places and must not be overlooked. Not only do malls provide traditional shopping, but they provide fianancial services (money transfers.....western union, money gram etc), and package delivery (DHL, UPS etc), along with being transportaion hubs for public utility vehichles (PUVS). This combination insures these places are always filled with people from opening to close.

I will share every mall in Cebu city proper with a brief description. Firstly, their are tiers of malls, and you will find a different type of person depending on the tier.
1. Ayala malls
2. Sm malls
3.Robinsons
4. Gaisano
5. Random shit. Puregold/fishermall/starmall/ ETC

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Cebu city mall list:

1. Ayala Center: This is the best mall in cebu city. Centrally located in the buisness district and equipped with a beautiful courtyard. Their are many nice hotels situated within walking distance to this malls. Freelance hookers can be found prowling, especially around bo's coffee, tgiFridays, and the Social (bar/lounge located on the top level.....infamous for foreigner hunters). Many food options here ranging from classic Filipino, to Greek. They have a cinema if going to the movies is your thing. Must visit if in Cebu city.

2. SM CITY: Oldest major mall (I think) in Cebu. Located on Ouano avenue (a main artery of Cebu). Every person will know how to get here by instinct, I would consider this as the proverbial heart of Cebu. The Radisson blu is connected to the mall (nicer hotel with great lobby), and the bayfront hotel is across the street (midrange hotel). The mall itself is showing it's age. They have a bowling alley and cinema for entertaining your family.

3. SM Seaside: Newest major mall situated on the main road leading out of Cebu City. It's also connected to the newly constructed bridge (CCLEX), so it's the closet major mall to those living/staying in LapuLapu city/Cordova. Nice complex with a kino roof area/lounge. Seaside has a cinema and a ice skating rink. The cebu ocean park is also connected to the mall......an okay aquarium by international standards, but with a nice restaurant attached.....kino views and very instagramable for your girlfriend.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2368769
4. Robinsons Galleria: Located just up the road from SM City. Has a decent hotel attached to the complex (summit galleria) . Has a tgifridays AND denny's (many memories of drunken fights at 3am in my local dennys in Miami.....here in the Philippines its a "classy" resturant LOOOL).

5. Robinsons Fuente: Located in Osmena circle, right up the street from the infamous mango square. On the first floor, theirs a vendor who sells "TOBACCO" pipes and rolling papers.....other than that it's not much in there except your standard fastfood and grocery store.

6. Parkmall: Located in Mandaue adjacent to BAI hotel. Mixed indoor/outdoor mall with a grocery store and lots of food options. Major transportation hub for PUV's. Good people watching in the afternoon for a more local flavor

7. City Times square: This can be considered part of parkmall as it right across the street. Outdoor stripmall type......has a few good bars and restaurants attached. Queensland hotel is here as well, for all your short time boomboom needs.

8. Pacific mall MANDAUE: Located just off the bridge coming from lapulapu city. Medium sized mall with your standard Jolibee/chowking offerings. Transportation hub for those headed into the northern suburbs of cebu

9. J Centre Mall (Jmall): Medium sized mall located in Mandaue. Most notable feature is their Bureau of Immigration office. If you live here as a foreigner for a while you will need to come here eventually. Decent hotel attached, and a nice bar (SENTRAL) located 1 minute walk away.

10. Elizabeth mall (Emall): Located adjacent to the south bus terminal. Smaller mall. Has a ghetto public school (ACT) attached, good place to people watch. For some reason I see ALOT of Africans in this mall, I can't fucking explain it, but I'm working on figuring it out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2368785
11. Ayala Central Block: Newer mall situated in IT park across the street from the park social and sugbu mercado. Lots of call center people open to foreigners around this area. Make sure to tell your driver AYALA in IT PARK, because if you just say "Ayala" they will take you to the Ayala center for sure.
12. JY Centre: Smaller mall in the Lahug neighborhood with a few food options, and a Mcdonalds for the Amerimutts. This is mainly used a jump off point for those going up into the mountains to see the TOPS viewpoint. Lots of motortaxi drivers will hang out here and try to take you up the mountain on a tour

13. Gaisano country mall: Outdoor Shopping area located in Mandaue. I've driven by this many times but never went in, so I can't really report as to what's there, but it IS THERE.

14. Gaisano Main/138 mall/Colonade: I've included these all together as they are in the same general vicinity (walking distance). All three of these are on, or very near to Colon street. Most Gaisano "malls" are not really malls so to speak, but more like big department stores. 138 and colonade sell a bunch of cheap knockoff shit from China, but theirs some good looking girls in there I'LL TELL YOU WHATTTTT

15.Gaisano Tisa/Gaisano jai alai/Gaisano mandaue central/Gaisano mandaue north: YEA theirs like 10 of these things in the greater Cebu area, I'm sure I'm missing some, so cebuBros correct me if I'm missing anything. These are more ghetto malls, your gonna see lots of flip flops, basketball shorts, knockoff basketball jerseys, and ankle bracelets. No frills here, this is a mall for locals.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369016
16. SM Consalacion: Smaller Sm mall located on the northern outskirts of Cebu. Kind of out the way if your staying in the city center, but it's the last stop before you start heading into the northern provinces.

17. Marina Mall: Located in LapuLapu city. This is mall in closet proximity to the airport. Standard jolibee/ chowking affair, nothing special. Their is another mall across the street (it's a gaisano mall), but as their is ANOTHER gaisano mall located a few meters down the road, I refer to both as Marina mall. The drivers have lived in the neighbnorhood their whole life and they still get the 2 malls mixed up, so just say Marina mall.

18. Gaisano Island mall: Located on lapu lapu a few meters from marina mall.....Known locally as Island mall. Theirs a beauru of immigration office inside, so if you live in lapulapu, its much more convient than going all the way into the city for your visa extensions.

19. Tamiya: This is an outdoor outlet style mall. On google maps, this is marked as "THE SHOPS AT PUEBLO VERDE", or "PUEBLO VERDE". If you tell a driver to take you to Pueblo verde, he will look at you like your stupid. For some reason everyone calls this area tamiya, you have to say tamiya or they won't know where the fuck you're talking about. I have many fond memories in Tamiya. Pre-pandemic they used to have a disco and a restobar in here, and I picked up quite a few girls just drinking in front of the 7/11 there (not hookers just horny young women). It's a bit more subdued now, but it's still a major transportation hub for LapuLapu city and they have several large factories nearby, so this place gets packed with people in the late afternoon. LOTS OF BEAUTIFUL GIRLS who work in factories making 200 dollars a month praying and hoping you'll save them can be found in this area. Try to brighten up their life, but don't take advantage please.

20. Grandmall Basak: Ghetto mall in the Basak neighborhood of lapulapu. Lots of boomers in here for some reason. They have alot of subdivisions nearby if you want to rent a house for a decent price.

21. Grandmall Cordova: It's not a mall, its a fucking department store. Somebody told me that if you go to the 7/11 just down the street in poblacion (just tell kuya 7/11 poblacion), horny girls will come to you and PICK YOU UP if you wait around long enough. LOL

This is a decent amount of time, and I'm probably just depends what type of stuff you like. The Subway can get you downtown in about an hour.

If you like touristy places and Korean culture, you probably want to visit the area around the main palace Gyongboekum(sp?). There's museums and art galleries in that area as well, and lots and lots of restaurants and different tourist shops. Insadong is a street close to there that you wouldn't want to miss.

The war museum in the national museum are also impressive, but there aren't many restaurants or shops around that area. If you go farther you will get to itaeeon which is the main foreigner area with lots of restaurants.

There's nature stuff to do too if you're into that. But it's pretty cold right now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm flying to Bangkok in February and the cheapest flights I found have a stopover in Mumbai or New Delhi.

Would it be worth staying in India for a week and checking out the city I fly into and some neighbouring region such as Goa?

I know it's not nearly enough to see the country but a lot of people say that you either love or hate it and I thought it'd make sense to get a taste of the country to see if I'd want to come back in the future for a longer, dedicated trip.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2378106
Yeah, may as well.

If you can choose where you're going, I'd opt for Mumbai and spend a few days in Goa or another nearby region. Delhi has a lot of historical sites, but it's also--bar-none--the worst introduction to India that first-time visitors could have. It's filthy, polluted, and crowded, and there are touts near every major attraction.

Both Goa and Mumbai have the same sorts of problems, but they're note quite as bad. Do be aware that Goa has an infamous "taxi mafia" that effectively controls non-private transportation in and around the beaches, so you'll end up paying more to get to your hotel than you would just about anywhere else in India.

If you have no choice but to go to Delhi, I'd recommend heading out to either Rajasthan or the Himalayas, depending on the weather at that time of year.

Realistically, you're only going to be able to see 1-2 different places--probably very typical, over-touristed places that are chock-full of touts and con artists. Nevertheless, you could have a fun time.
Alternatively, you could be a right cunt and just hop on a cheap domestic flight somewhere else, be it Kerala, Karnataka, or some ooga-booga city in Telangana or Odisha.

You will have to pick and choose, though. If you only have a week, you should either stay in the same city and make a day-trip somewhere nearby, or piss off ASAP. Everything takes time in India, and simply traveling to and from Goa from Mumbai would eat up 10-15 hours each way (unless you're flying).

>Bamako
I was working in Bamako and Mali last year. I checked the route and it basically goes through the safest area of Mali but I'd still want to check up on the organization and security for the Mali leg of this "rally". There were terrorist attacks in the past two years in this area against whites, as close as 60km west of Bamako city proper.

Bamako itself is pretty safe. Keep in mind all whites there are basically working for the UN, NGO:s, foreign government aid or are old French colonists who are well-connected after living in the country for generations (and most of those have left, the rest have moved into Bamako). All the foreigners belong to an organization and have some sort of security backup available and most are armed themselves.

Outside of Bamako there's pretty much only military camps. Possibly some civilian NGO presence in Timbuktu or Gao but I very much doubt it, the only ones I know of are contractors who rent space to be interred within military camps and coordinate their own movements with military patrols for protection.

Pretty much every "private traveller" who've gone against recommendations and decided to visit/drive through Mali outside of Bamako have been kidnapped and are now dead or in somewhere in the desert. A couple of guys were ransomed by private actors after like 6 years as captives. This was according to a couple of embassies security info last year (European countries).

Ofc, if you are black you can probably disregard alot of this, as long as you can blend in and not stand out as a rich Westerner.

I love adventurous travel but after working for NGO:s a few years I would never visit a country in an armed conflict/in civil war after knowing how easily your luck can run out. It's far more common than you think.

>>2377371
This year, the rally ended in Freetown instead of Bamako due to the security issues. We'll see what the actual route looks like for 2024.

>after working for NGO:s a few years I would never visit a country in an armed conflict/in civil war
I used to work for an NGO that had/has pretty close ties with various Marxist revolutionary groups in Africa. All the old hands had stories about working during the civil wars in Mozambique and Angola or vacationing in Western Sahara and hanging out with Polisario. I get the impression that, while it was maybe a dangerous situation, there was little danger to them specifically. The same guys recently had to close up shop at a few projects in northern Mozambique due to Al Qaeda attacks. I guess they don't make insurgent groups like they used to.

>if you are black you can probably disregard alot of this
This is surprisingly not the case. I used to work with a Zimbabwean guy in central Mozambique. His home village couldn't have been more than a couple hundred miles away, and the tribal language there was basically the same as the one where we worked. To my eyes, he was indistinguishable from the locals, but people there could somehow immediately pick him out as a foreigner. It was like he glowed. He was constantly getting hassled by police.

The local word for a white person where I worked was "muzungu", and I and other white folks working there were pretty accustomed to hearing people yelling "muzungu! muzungu!" while we were going about normal day-to-day activities like riding our bikes to work or shopping in the market. The guy from Zimbabwe and another colleague from Sudan constantly got singled out as foreigners, but nobody called them muzungus. On the other hand, our black colleague from the US got the same "muzungu! muzungu!" treatment that the white folks got. She was so excited to be in "the motherland", and she would get so pissed off when people called her muzungu. It was great.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2378509
I do live here! Here are some places that could be worth a visit:

- Széllkapu: nice freshly renovated garden
- Budai vár: castle district with cute small streets and nice viewpoints on the city
- Rudas fürdő: my fave bath with a jacuzzi on the rooftop
- Gellért hegy: hill near the city centre with a nice view and a big ass statue and flag on top
- Szent István bazilika: tallest point in the city centre (also a beautiful building obviously)
- Magyar Zene Háza and Néprajzi múzeum: very new really interesting buildings near Hősök tere
- Tram no. 2: most beautiful tramroute in the world
- Mélypont: retro pub with a huge selection of whisky rum beer etc. in a nice neighbourhood
- Vaj: really good bakery, a bit pricey for locals but whatever
- Retro Élményközpont: nostalgic museum to get a glimpse of old era Budapest
- Terror Háza: museum of communist crimes (there's also a piece of the Berlin Wall there for example)
- Pinczi Hús és Hentesüzlet: to try local quick food ask for kolbász + császár + mustár + kenyér + kovászos uborka + Dreher

I will post some more if something pops up! Have fun!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hi /trv/,

I'll be getting a decent chunk of money this summer and will have approximately the first three weeks of August to do some traveling. I've been hoping to take a big trip for a few years but was stopped by first the pandemic and then some work obligations.

So, hoping to take a big trip as cheaply as possible, but willing to spend up to ~$4000. I speak only English and high school Spanish, and am interested in architecture, culture, sightseeing generally, walking around at night. I like hiking but am not especially interested in dealing with the hassle of renting a car or dealing with confusing and unreliable bus companies -- I'll be coming off a long period of hard work and while I want something more active than lounging on the beach, I don't want to deal with *logistical* hassle.

So, what I've been considering (in order) is:

- Japan (wanted to go for a while, figure it's easy enough to figure out the trains etc)
- Europe (never been, would want to do something like Paris / Italy / Vienna)
- Singapore or Korea (seem cool but not sure I'd want to spend three whole weeks there)
- North Africa (really interested in Morocco, Gibraltar, Tunis, Tripoli, Algiers, but it seems like this would require significantly more planning)
- South America (really interested in Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina, Peru, but again, seems like this would be more complicated than Japan/Europe).

Anyone have any thoughts on any of the above, or any other recommendations? China is the one place I've been, so even though I haven't been to a lot of the cities, I'm not especially interested in going back for this trip.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2360364
I know Madrid has been mentioned already, but Barcelona is by FAR my favourite city in the world to stay in, especially long term. I'm eventually planning on moving there.

For me, Barcelona is the perfect mix of a big, industrial modern cosmopolitan city, with beautiful historic architecture and a refreshing combination of both chilled out beach/party/tourist elements and normal every-day working life.

Madrid is very similar, except a more conservative, more administrative city with far less touristic/party elements. For me, I could explore Barcelona for several weeks, seeing new parts of the city, meeting people from all over the world, visiting interesting museums, relaxing at different beaches and eating at different types of restaurants and not get bored. I could probably only do the same in Madrid for several days.

Honestly, I don't have a single negative thing to say about Barcelona.
